it is the principal street in Boyle. Bridge Street: This street is so called because there is a bridge in it. "Dun na Mias": This is a town land, which is situated about two miles from the town and it means the "fort of the Dishes".Assylinn: This is the name given to a district, and it means "eas an Fhlionn" or the "waterfall of the O'Flionn".



There is no name given or known for a leipreachan but a "leipreachan"
(continues on next page)

4758456/4745580/4770465.title: Leipreachán Stories
4758456/4745580/4770465.text:
(continued from previous page)
fishing on the lake was drowned, so that the mermaid is supposed to come ashore when any person named Glynn is going to be drowned.



There are very few stories told in my district about leipreachans or mermaids. No one has ever seen one but from what they have read in books. They say that a leipreachan is a little dwarf about the size of a man's fist. He is usually a cobbler and anyone who is lucky enough to find him will get him sitting under a plant or mushroom working away at his boots. He is supposed to have a purse of
(continues on next page)

4758456/4745582/4770470.title: Leipreachán Stories
4758456/4745582/4770470.text:
(continued from previous page)
the leipreachan shouted and said "Your house in on fire." The girl gave a great start and looked towards the house which was alright, but alas, when she looked for the leipreachan he was gone.



In Ardcarne which is situated three miles from Boyle there is a leipreachan to be seen every five years. If you want to get a pot of gold from him he brings you down into a field which is situated beside the graveyard of Ardcarne.The leipreachan brings you as far as a wild cat who is guarding the pot of gold. The wild cat is really an old witch and if the person whom the leipreachan brings down succeeds in killing
(continues on next page)

4706343/4704379/4770608.title: The Leipreachan or Mermaid
4706343/4704379/4770608.text: The Leipreachan is known in this district as the Lutharagan. He is about two feet high and is dressed in green with a red caroline hat. It is not known where he lives. Shoemaking is his usual occupation. Stories of local people who saw him are recorded. These people never caught him nor endeavoured to get him to give up his gold. Leipreachans are looked upon as friendly beings but it is not locally recorded that they ever helped human beings. It is not known if anybody ever interfered with them or if they tried to have revenge.The mermaid is not known in this district.

4758456/4745759/4778580.title: Leipreachán Stories
4758456/4745759/4778580.text:
In ancient times, the people of our district used to tell quite a number of old tales connected with the fairy folk, especially lepreachauns, but most of the old inhabitants of the district have died long since, bringing most of those old stories to the grave with them. Some of those old stories are still told by the old inhabitants, but there is one in particular told about the fairy cobbler of Lough Erid.Once upon a time there lived on the shores of Lough Erid, which is situated about two miles east of Ballyfarnon, a poor widow and her son, Padraig Mulvany. Padraig was a
(continues on next page)

4758456/4745763/4778581.title: Leipreachán Stories
4758456/4745763/4778581.text:
(continued from previous page)
but on still nights her weird caoining can be heard for miles around. It is said that she is mourning Sean O'Connor, the boy who gave up his young life for the love of her.



Near Boyle is situated the fairies' Hill and it is said that many people have seen the little man known as the Leipreachan. It is held that he is very tiny and is always at work with hammer and shoes. He is said to wear red apparel and once it is believed that someone caught him.The man asked him if he would show him the pot of gold and he promised he would if he pledged never to come
(continues on next page)

4758456/4745766/4778582.title: Lepreachán Stories
4758456/4745766/4778582.text:
There is a lot of stories told in my district which are connected with leipreachans and mermaids. Here I will relate to you a few of the most commonly known ones. These little creatures were known as "Lurgadans" in some parts of the country. It was said that if anyone was up at a very early hour on may morning that they would surely get the 'Lurgadán". This little fellow is dressed in a red suit and cap, and there is a long bag of money tied around his neck. It is said that if anyone should catch one of those Lurgadans he would have enough money all his life. There was a lot of attempts made to catch him especially by children but none of them was successful. This little man was supposed to be very cute, and if
(continues on next page)

4713260/4712608/4779421.title: (no title)
4713260/4712608/4779421.text: There was a fairy there long ago called the Leprecán. He had a pot of gold. The man that could catch him would be very rich. But no one could catch the fairy because he was too clever. Everyone that captured him he made a wonder and they looked round when they would look again he would be gone. He would put them looking for his pot of gold.Darby ODonoghue age 14 years.Maurice J ODonoghue 49 years Rusheenbeg

4713261/4712765/4779796.title: Leprachaun
4713261/4712765/4779796.text: One evening two boys were going for the cows. They had a course piece of down near the Dooloughs in Droumdirralough called the eáol. They used to go for the cows every evening. One evening as they were bringing toe cows they sas a small man wearing a red jacket and he beckoned at them to come towards them but they ran off in terror of their lives. But in all probability had they waited they might have got some of the gold.

4758457/4746014/4782325.title: Leipreachans
4758457/4746014/4782325.text:
2. There is a story told about a mermaid who lived long ago. There were some men standing on the shore and they saw a ruffling coming on the waves and there came out a mermaid and she went to one of them and said "Come here on this day twelve months at sun-set and you will get three of the finest cows of the land" Bo Finn, Bo Dubh, Bo Dearg. When the men heard that they were glad and they brought her round the country. Then she said that she  like to go back again and they brought her. She said to them to come on the day after that and
(continues on next page)

4758457/4746015/4782327.title: Leipreachans
4758457/4746015/4782327.text:
(continued from previous page)
they would get the cows. They got the cows and soon the breed of those cows spread through the country and that is why the white, the red, and the black cows are the best, so it is said.



3. Once upon a time there was a Leipreachan. He lived under a mushroom and at night he used to make shoes. Round twelve o'clock he used to be heard hammering . One night a certain man was trying to find him
(continues on next page)

4758468/4746642/4782762.title: A Leipreacháin
4758468/4746642/4782762.text: There was leipreachán near Flemmings old house.One night John Fleming's father was going stealing a bag of turf.  As he was coming with the bag of turf the leipreachán met him.  The man had the dog with him and he started fighting with the leipreacháh.The dog would not let him near the man.  When they got to the house himself and the dog went in and the leipreachán stayed outside.  When the man went out to milk the cow the leipreachán followed him.There was a loft over the cows and the leipreachán went up in it and started playing a fiddle.  The man went in for a shovel full of coals and he threw them up in the loft to the leipreachán.  The leipreachán haunted him ever after that until he died.

4758462/4746359/4782945.title: The Leipreachan or Mermaid
4758462/4746359/4782945.text:
The Leipreachan is a very small man, he dresses in red, and wears big shoes, with the tops of them turned up.  He is very often called the "Fairy shoemaker."  He sits under a mushroom making shoes.  In Ireland, long ago, and they had tiny men working for them, these rich people were always thinking, that someone would steal their gold.
(continues on next page)

4742166/4741308/4783901.title: Houses
4742166/4741308/4783901.text:
(continued from previous page)
them. There were half-doors in the houses. These were very useful. Before paraffin oil came out the people had to invent lights of their own. They used to have rushlights, bog-dale splinters, and other things for light.



The Leiprecaun is a little fairy man. He is sometimes called a "Clúracan". He is about a foot high. He is dressed very prettily
(continues on next page)

4742166/4741374/4784074.title: The Leprechaun
4742166/4741374/4784074.text:
The Leprecaun.The Leprecaun is a little fairy man.  He is dressed in a red coat, green trousers, yelllow conical cap with silk stockings and black patent shoes with silver buckles.  He only comes out on a moonlight night.  He sits on a caise puca under a lone bush.  He mends fairy mens shoes and he also puts shoes on the fairy horses.  While he is shoeing the fairy horses he sings.Tick, tack, too a nail in your shoeGentleman your horse is shodHe has a jug of (the)
(continues on next page)

4770026/4767694/4786733.title: The Leprechaun
4770026/4767694/4786733.text:
The Leipreachan is a very small man who is often called a fairy. He lives under a mushroom and spends most of his time making boots. He generally keeps a jug of beer by his side. He wears a green cloak and a tall red cap and long pointed shoes.The Leipreachan is supposed to know where there is gold hidden and anyone who catches him may have a chance of getting the gold but he must be very clever as the Leipreachan himself is very clever and plays a great many tricks on anyone who catches him. Anyone who catches him must not take
(continues on next page)

4758500/4749177/4813371.title: The Leprechaun
4758500/4749177/4813371.text:
Some year's ago a man Edward Grace Ballyhomuck was coming from a threshing dance. On his way home he had to pass by a rath. This rath belonged to James Mc Donnell Ballyhomuck. This dance was held at James Freney house. Fearneogue. It was about twelve o'clock in the night when he was coming home and he was frightened because he heard fairy stories about this road before. When he was passing this rath he heard the noise of a hammer in the rath. He looked, and under a mushroom he saw a tiny man. This little man was a Leprechaun. He was dressed in a very old fashioned style. He had on him a red jacket and a white trousers and a red cap with a large tosell and shoes curved up at the top. This man Edward Grace Ballyhomuck who died some years ago passed slowly by and the Leprechaun did not hear him because
(continues on next page)

4770030/4767992/4813943.title: The Leipreachán
4770030/4767992/4813943.text: We call this little man a leipreachán.  He is only about six inches in height, people say he is only as big as your fist.  He wears a tall red cap and a blue gown, red shoes with big pointed toes.  It is said he lives under a lone bush.  People say if you be kind to him he will be kind to you, he would give you a pot of gold.  This little man is always making shoes for the fairies to dance.  When you want money and if (I) you bring food to the leipreachan he will give you a pot of gold.  It is said if you cut down a lone bush the fairies will always be annoying you and, people say (and people say) you will never have an hours luck.  When you are in bed they are supposed to knock at the door or window and if you go up you will see no one.  If you do anything to a leipreachán he is sure to have revenge.

4770030/4767993/4813947.title: The Leipreachán
4770030/4767993/4813947.text:
This fairy is called the Leipreachan.  He is said to be a very small little fellow.  People say he is dressed in red.  He lives under a fairy tree in (il) a glen.  He makes shoes and boots for the fairies to dance with.  There is a glen at the of our house, and fairies are supposed to have lived in it long ago.  I never heard any stories about the Leipreachan.  I never heard of the Leipreachan helping people.

from work at nightfall.  He went into a shady grove to light his pipe at the Strand.  When he had his pipe lit he saw a wee man standing beside him.  The man was frightened and looked at the little man.  Then the little man disappeared.  The man said it was a leipreachan



The leipreachan is about six inches high.  He wears a tall hat and a red jacket.  He lives under a tree in the middle of a field.  It is said if you cut down a tree where the leipreachan is supposed to be he will come around the house.  He earns his money by making shoes.Sometime you might hear "tic-tac tic-tac" well that would be the leipreachan making shoes.

4770030/4767995/4813962.title: The Leipreachán
4770030/4767995/4813962.text: The leopreachan weare a purple coat and a red cap. His height is about six inches.When the sun is going down he sits under a lone tree making shoes for the fairies. They give him gold and silver for making the shoes. He has a little pot and he puts his money into the little pot. You would want to be very quick to get his money.

4758501/4749277/4814009.title: The Leprechaun
4758501/4749277/4814009.text: The little fairy man is called the Cluaracan round this district. He was said to live in raths or in beds where the hare lied. People thought him to be about a foot and a half high. They often watched for hours in the evenings to see could they catch him in raw fields or in hollows or any lonely places. They thought him to stay in raws during the day mending shoes or making potheen and that he came out at dushish and went round lonely places. It was very hard to catch him because he had many tricks to keep people from getting his purse. It was said that the Cluaracan's purse is never empty. If one happened to get the Cluaracan's money he would get it back some other way or do some harm to the person who meddled with him. Very seldom he was caught because it was said that one took their eyes off him while they were following him he would never be seen. The Cluaracan is hardly ever spoken of at present.

4758501/4749278/4814010.title: The Leprechaun
4758501/4749278/4814010.text: The Leprachan is locally known as the Luricán. He lives in raths or in hares' beds. When people are out late at night he runs across the road and if the person ran after him he would throw balls of gold at him and if they picked up the gold he would disappear. When they kept watching and running after he would give them a purse of gold and the purse can never be emptied but the person never lives long after that. His principal work is mending shoes and making poteen under a mushroom He wears a red jacket and a red cap. He grows to a height of eighteen inches.

4758501/4749279/4814011.title: The Leprechaun
4758501/4749279/4814011.text: The name that the fairy man is known by in my home district is the Leprachaun and the Lurachan. He is always making shoes and he is supposed to be living in the old raths. He wears a small green jacket, a small red cap and very big shoes. He always carries a small hammer and a last. if anybody could catch him he would promise them gold if they would let him go and he would promise to meet him in a certain place and when the person would go there he would not give them the gold at all. He is said to be about twelve or fifteen inches in height.

4758501/4749280/4814013.title: The Leprechaun
4758501/4749280/4814013.text: The fairy man that in this district is called the Leprachaun. He is dressed in a green jacket and a red cap and big shoes. He is about a foot high and is always making shoes. He carries a small hammer and a shoe last. He is supposed to live in old raths. Anyone that would cath him he would he would promise them gold and tell them to meet him in a certain place and when they would go there he would not be in it

4758501/4749281/4814015.title: The Leprechaun
4758501/4749281/4814015.text: The leprachan is called the Cluaracan in this district. He is supposed to be about six inches high. His work is mending shoes. He lives in a rath or under a mushroom. If he were caught he would give you a crock of gold but if you took your eyes off him he would dissappear. He wears a green jacket a red cap about a foot long a white pants and a large pair of shoes that are coming to a point.

4758501/4749282/4814017.title: The Leprechaun
4758501/4749282/4814017.text: In this district the little fairy man is called a Leprachan. He is said to spend all his time on moonlight nights' in some field where he could find a big mushoom mending shoes. He wears white pants a red coat, brown leggings and a tall green cap with a tassel on the top. He is about two feet high. A man named William Fleming who lived in a little house at the bottom of Mullnahone hill caught the Leprachan one night. He tried to take his purse from him, but the Leprachan told him to look first at the big man that was behind him. The man looked but when he looked back the Leprachan was gone.

4758501/4749283/4814019.title: The Leprechaun
4758501/4749283/4814019.text: The name that the Leprecháun gets in this locality is the Luaracán. He is said to make his living by making shoes under a mushroom. He is said to wear a red jacket and a red cap. He is about six inches. No one ever saw him in this locaity. He is said to have a purse of money which would never be empty no mater how much money would be taken out of it. He is said to wear very long shoes with the toes of turned up.

4758501/4749284/4814020.title: The Leprechaun
4758501/4749284/4814020.text: The name that the people have for the Leprecháun in our district is the Luracháun. He wears a red jacket and a green cap, and very long shoes. He was seen mending sores, with a small hamer in his right hand. He is said to be about eighteen inches high, and he was seen in an old rath, and he ran into burrow in the ground.

4758501/4749285/4814021.title: The Leprechaun
4758501/4749285/4814021.text: The name that the fairy man is known by is the Leprechan and Lúracán. He wears a small red jacket a blue cap and very big shoes. He always carries a small hammer and a shoe last If anybodys would catch he would promise them a pot of gold if they would let him go He would promise to meet them in a certain place He is said to be about a foot in height

4770034/4768230/4815279.title: The Leipreachan
4770034/4768230/4815279.text:
The Lepreachan is said to be the fairy boot maker and mender.  He is a small man with a long grey beard, and he is dressed in bright colours.  People go hunting Leprechauns at night time in fairy forts.  He is said to carry a purse of gold.  One must ask him three times before they get it.  Between the second & third time the Lepreachan makes a loud noise and it seems to be behind one.  Then he asks the person to look around and when he turns the lepreachan has vanished.  Here is a story about the lepreachan.  There were two soldiers on time at war and they lay down under a tree to

4742056/4731355/4815593.title: Leipreacháin
4742056/4731355/4815593.text:
At Stranooden fort and Tallenclave fort Leipreacháins were seen. People saw them marching from one fort to the other. A man named Molloy lived near the Forts and he was a cobbler. His house was L shaped. He said to his neighbours that he often saw the wee men, who were dressed in green coats and red hats mending shoes outside the fort on bright moonlight nights.One night he tried to capture one, but the little man gave an awful shout and Molloy took his eyes off the Leipreacháin  to see what gave him such a fright. When he looked where the "wee man" was he had disappeared. From that night out he never saw the Leipreacháin again.

4713226/4709464/4817061.title: The Leipreachán or Mermaid
4713226/4709464/4817061.text: The Leipreachan is known locally as Luthargan. He is a very small man dressed in red. His work is making shoes and he is called a fairy shoemaker. He lived under the ground and is supposed to have a crock of gold hidden somewhere. The townland of Knochaurnna is enchanted with luthargans and several people have caught them but they got no gold.A mermaid is half a woman and half a fish, she is supposed to have a very valuable cap.Once a man carried a mermaid's cap and he kept it. When ever he went any where he locked the cap in a press and carried the key with him. One day he was going on a journey and forgot to take the key of the press. The mermaid got the key, opened the press and found the cap. She had seven children and they were also mermaids. She set out for the sea and took the children with her. When the man came home they were gone and he never again saw either the children or the mermaid.The Mulcahys of this district are connected with mermaids. Their great grandmother was a mermaid.

4742116/4737435/4817283.title: An Leipreachán
4742116/4737435/4817283.text: An Leipreachán	Do bhí bean ann fadó darab ainm “Síghle an Gaduidhe.”  Fuair sí an ainm sin toisg go dtéigheadh sí amach ins d’oidhche ag goid.  Oidhche amháin ana-dhéanach ag dul abhaile di cé bhfeachaidh sí acht an “Leipreachán.”  Do bhí sé ‘na shuidhe fé crann mór daraighe, ag déanamh bróg, agus cóta agus bríste de leathar bog air.	Nuair a chonnaic sí é d’aithin sí go maith é, agus chuimhnig sí ar na bprócha óir bhíodh aige.  D’ealuigh sí taobh thiar de agus rug sí greim daingean air, agus dúbhairt sí ós árd, “Amach le d’próca óir.”  “Tabhair abhaile mé agus cuir sa comharainn mé agus tabhairfaidh mé duit é,” ar seisean léi.  Rug sí léi abhaile é, agus chuir sí fé ghlas sa cómharainn é.  	I gceann tamaill tháinig sí airís cun an prócha d’fághail acht do bhí an leipreachán imthighthe agus píosa páipéir ina ionad agus na focail seo sgríbhte air:-“Is mairg ná feachann roimis.”Pádraig De Búrca, do sgríobhMicheál Ua Siochfradha (60) d’aithrisCúl na hAirigílGleannbeithe.

4769952/4762472/4819360.title: The Leipreachán
4769952/4762472/4819360.text:
One evening a poor man was walking through fields when he spied a Leprachaun under a tree. He had a red coat and a green cap. The man caught the Leprachaun and asked him where the gold was hidden. The Leprachaun gave him a crock of gold and told him not to go near the glen where he used to work. The man promised he would not. That evening the man invited his friends to a party in the summer-house. After the party when they were all gone the leprachaun broke down the walls of the summer-house. When the old man went home he found he was living in his old home again.



It was on the 24th June when two children went for a walk in the woods. They sat down and heard tip-tap, tip-tap, as a bird hitting something with its beak. They looked down and saw a leprachaun working away on a small shoe. Tom and Mary were the two children's names

4798670/4788908/4823796.title: A Leipreacán or Merry Maid
4798670/4788908/4823796.text:
The "leipreacán" is sometimes called a fairy.  He is very small.  Some people say he is no bigger than six inches.  He wears a red jacket, a green trousers and pointed boots.  He lives in forts and raths.  He is all the time making shoes and boots like those which he wears himself.  Some people think he keeps acrock of gold and they try to catch him in order to get the gold from him but those people do not very often succeed.  Sometimes the "leapreacán" helps people.  If anyone does any harm to the leapreacán he keeps it in mind for them.  Another magic witch who

4798666/4788505/4823841.title: Story - The Leprechaun
4798666/4788505/4823841.text: Story - The LeprechaunOne day when John Dowd was coming from a fair in Ballaghaderreen he came to the avenue on the bus and when he came down the avenue he came to John Morrisroe's field.There was a small man sitting against an old tree in the middle of the field; his back was turned and he did not see or hear John so John walked quietly over to the tree and caught him and said "Hand out your money." Where would I get money said the Leprechaun" and John continued asking the money and the Leprechaun continued saying that he had no money and at last he said that he had money but that it was in his home.He said to John that it would not take them long to go to his home so they set out in the direction of his home. when they came near the place the Leprechaun said to John "what is that behind you" John looked behind him and the Leprechaun made his escape and disappeared so John had to return without the money.

4798657/4787607/4923033.title: The Leprechaun
4798657/4787607/4923033.text: The Laipreacan[-]The Leipreacan is known by no other name but Leipreacan in this part of the country. He generally is seen under a mushroom or small tree One morning when my grandfather, John Walsh (deceased), was coming home from a dance, he saw what he thought was a Leipreacan in the land of Mrs. Walsh, Deerpark, Boyle. He was sitting under a tree making a pair of boots. He wore a small tight fitting coat, a very tight-fitting trousers, and a very long-shanked pair of shoes. Something tempted my grandfather to look round, and when he turned again the Leipreacan was gone.

4798684/4789984/4923422.title: Leprechauns
4798684/4789984/4923422.text: In this district the Leiprechan is known as the sidhe-og. This being is about six or seven inches tall and dresses in a knee breeches, red jacket and green hat. He also wears pointed shoes which he makes himself. He lives in an earthen fence or a hole in the ground near a lios or fort.At midnight he is to be found fixing shoes under a mushroom or dock-leaf. He keeps his pot of gold beside him. A man from this district caught him. The Leiprechan told him his gold was buried in a certain spot, but when the man dug for it he found nothing.

4798698/4791173/4924473.title: A Story about a Leipreachán
4798698/4791173/4924473.text:
A story about a LeiprecanA Leipreacan is about the size of your knee dressed in a coat of red from top to toe. he lives in a forth along with a number of other fairies. he is also the fairy shoemaker. The old people used to say that if you caught a Leipreacan and threatened to kill him that he would give you a crock of gold but he would try all his tricks before he would consent to give you the treasure. He would say "Oh Look at the big bull that is running after you" If you were foolish enough to look about you, you would be tricked From once you lose sight of him you can never see him again. Another job of his is minding a crock of gold under a tree near a forth. It was the Danes that hid that money in those forths and left the Leipreacans to mind it when Brian Brow attacked them. It is said that in the olden days a woman of this district caught a Leipreacan and swore she would kill him if he would not give her gold. The poor little creature did not know what to do. At last he consented to give he some. The woman was so delighted when she got it that she never thanked him but ran in and began telling the people of all the gold she was after obtaining, then she opened her apron to show them it, and to her amazement found that it was full of her skirts of leaves. This is a song about a Leipreacan
(continues on next page)

4798659/4787799/4924910.title: Leprechauns
4798659/4787799/4924910.text:
I have heard the following story from my grandfather. Once there lived in Corrigeenroe a man named McGinty. One night he was rambling in one of the neighbours houses. When he was coming home he met three little Leipreachans and they asked McGinty if he would come with them and pick the bride. McGinty "agreed" and they put him riding on a bohalaun. Now McGinty was changed into a Leipreachans also and they kept going over hill and over hollow and they never stopped until they came to a house. They entered and they went upstairs. Then they ate and drank and when they had enough, they made a hole in the ground. The bride was underneath them and they made this hole to look down at her. Before they could take her up she had to sneeze three times. So one of the Leipreachans got a wisp and he put it down in the hole and tickled her nose and she sneezed once. He did the same thing again and she sneezed twice, and he did it again and she sneezed three times. Then McGinty looked down at her and he fell down, and there he was a big man as usual. Then he was in Riverstown which was nine miles from his own home and he had to walk the
(continues on next page)

4798709/4792255/4925177.title: Leprechauns
4798709/4792255/4925177.text: LeprachaunsLong ago in Ireland the people believed in Leprechauns, fairies, and other evil spirits. Tradition tells us that there was a Leprachaun seen in this vicinity some years ago.One night as a man Hanly was returning home from a neighbour's house he was supposed to have captured a Leprachaun. It was a moonlight night and the Leprachaun was sitting under a tree, dressed in a red coat and hat. When the man saw him he rushed at him. He ordered him, to hand him a purse of gold or he would take his life, but the Leprachaun made no reply.  Then, said the fairy, "what is that I see over yonder". The man looked in the direction shown him by the fairy, but when he turned, the fairy had vanished and he was never seen again.

4798709/4792256/4925179.title: Leprechauns
4798709/4792256/4925179.text: LeprachaunsThere was once a Leprachaun seen in a fort at Curries, by a man named Shannon. He heard him hammering at shoes as it were, when he was working in his own land near by. This happened on one or two occasions.So he went into the fort this evening and saw him sitting under a mushroom soleing shoes. He tried to catch him but failed. He watched after him a long time but could not catch him.

4798709/4792257/4925181.title: Leprechauns
4798709/4792257/4925181.text: LeprachaunsThere is a story that was told to me a few years ago about a leprachaun that was seen in this district years ago.One evening an old man was coming home from his work. He had to pass a large wood. As he was walking along he heard the sound of a hammer. He looked around and at last saw a very small man sitting under a tree.This man was mending boots. The old man went over to where he was sitting.They started to talk to each. After a while, he told the old man that he would dream that night where there was a pot of gold. But he told him not to tell anyone about it or if he did so the pot of gold would not be there. The man went home but foolishly enough he told another man on his way home. The man dreamt where the pot of gold was, but when he went there he could not find the gold.

4798709/4792258/4925184.title: Leprechauns
4798709/4792258/4925184.text: LeprachaunsThere was a story told to me once about a Leprachaun. Here it is.Once upon a time there was a man and woman going to the town of Carrick on Shannon in their ass and cart. The man saw a Leprachaun in some field in the Corries.The woman told the man to go over and catch him. The man went over and caught him.The Leprachaun told the man that if he let him go he would grant him three wishes. The man did so. Not long after the ass was going slow. The man said he wished he had a stick. No sooner had he said it than a stick leaped into the cart." Thats one fine wish gone" said the woman". I wished you had it up in you" and the stick went up in him. The man then had one wish and then he wished to get it down.And so ended the three wishes.

4798709/4792259/4925187.title: Leprechauns
4798709/4792259/4925187.text: LeprachaunsI knew a man one time and he told me he caught a Leprachaun. The mans name was Reynolds. This is the way he caught him.The man was walking about the field and he saw a little man beside him. He put out his two hands to catch him. He caught him and he kept his two eyes on him. The man asked him where he would get a pot of gold and the Leprachaun said. There is a black god coming behind'. When the man took his eyes off him he went away. This is the story told in my district about the leprachaun.

4798709/4792260/4925196.title: Leprechauns
4798709/4792260/4925196.text:
LeprauchaunsLong ago the Irish people loved to hear stories about Leprauchauns, and even we hear stories about these spirits to the present day. It is supposed that a man named Beirne seen a Leprauchaun in the Visinity of Curgullion. This is how the story goes.It happened one moonlight night, as he was passing through his own paddock, in the corner of which was the remains of an old fort, that he saw sitting on the stump of an old oak tree a little man dressed in red with a bag of gold on his back. The little man spoke to Beirne by his name, and he taking courage asked him what he had in the little bag. "Money said the Leprauchaun, and I will give it to you if you race me for it". Beirne ran after him, and made a grab for the bag of gold, but all Beirne caught was an old fairy mushroom. He raced the Leprauchaun five times round the paddock and Beirne was so near the Leprauchaun that he caught him by the tail of the coat, but it feel out of his hands, and
(continues on next page)

4798660/4787931/4926162.title: Haunted House
4798660/4787931/4926162.text:
(continued from previous page)
the ghost went up the chimney. He got caught in a pipe going out and when there was a big fire put down the smoke blew him out of the chimney.In another house in Boyle there are too rooms shut and there is supposed to be a ghost in them.



The Irish people believed in the leprachauns. If they caught one they would be rich ever after, he was supposed to be always guarding a pot of gold. If you were lucky enough to catch him you would have to keep your eye on him. If you looked away from him he would disappear. The leprachaun is a small man about nine inches high. He
(continues on next page)

4758566/4755218/4926602.title: Old Houses
4758566/4755218/4926602.text:
(continued from previous page)
candles was very simple. They boiled tallow and plaited thread and dipped it in the tallow and hung it on a stick across the room. When it would be dry they would dip the thread in the tallow again and let it harden again. They kept on doing this till the candles were as thick as an ordinary candle. Rushlights were made in much the same way only that the inside of rushes was used instead of thread for a wick. Those candles gave very bad light and some of the people were blind. There were very few chairs used in those times, only stools and blocks.



A man in this district named Paddy Dullard saw two leipreachans one Sunday morning when he was going home from Mass at about ten o'clock. They were outside Ballyfoyle Castle and they had red coats and caps on them. He said they were about thirty inches high. There was a leipreachán living in a field in Corbettstown called Paurk Philip. He was said to be minding money there and was seen by
(continues on next page)

4758566/4755253/4926695.title: Food in Old Times
4758566/4755253/4926695.text:
(continued from previous page)
water during Lent and on fast days."Barley bread would kill a man dead.Beare bread would do no harm.Oaten bread would clear the blood andWheaten bread would strengthen the arm.



The Leipreachán is called by various names such as Luterdan and Geanncack. He is two foot six inches high. He wears a red cap a red trousers and a white jumper. He lives in the woods and he is mending boots all day and singing. A man named Deegan caught a leipreachan one time and would not let him off until he would give him the gold. Paddy Dullard saw two leipreacháns one day. He was working with Mr. Comerford of Ballyfoyle and he saw them going across the field as if they were going towards the glen. There was a story told about a man who was very rich. He was afraid that his purse of gold would be stolen. There was a small honest man working with him and the man asked him to take care of his gold. The
(continues on next page)

4758558/4754590/4927079.title: The Leprechaun
4758558/4754590/4927079.text:
The Leprecaun July 23rd 1934Once upon a time there was a boy who rose early one morning and ment in search of a four leaved shamrock  as a birthday present for his mother. Agter a long search he could not get it so he started for home because he did not want them to know at home that he was gone and he was afraid they would be up. When he as a little way he met a fairy who asked him what he was looking for. He told her  and she went with him to look for it. They came to the leprecaun and he told the boy he would give it to him for some gold. The boy had a new penny and he told him he would give it to him for the shamrock. Then the leprecaun told the boy to give him the penny first but the boy would not, Then the fairy took the penny and shamrock and stood in the middle of two trees, then she told them to run and who ever would reach the tree first
(continues on next page)

4798684/4789985/4927475.title: Leprechauns
4798684/4789985/4927475.text: A Leiprechans is a tine little man about six inches in height. He is dressed in a bright red jacket and wears a tall cap.It is said that Leiprechans are to be seen shoemaking in forts about midnight. Stories are told of people who saw Leiprechans long ago. They kept their eyes on the Leiprechan until he told them where his gold was hidden. He usually told the people it was buried under some stone or bush near the fort, but when they dug for the gold they usually did not find it.

4798684/4789986/4927476.title: A Leprechaun
4798684/4789986/4927476.text: A leiprechan is generally called a fairy. He is only a feur inches tall. He usually lives under a tree in a wood. He is so tiny that he can fit under a muchroom.Leiprechans are able to do all classes of work, but they are generally engaged in shoemaking. They are supposed to have a jar of gold hidden under a tree, in a castle or under a hill. People often went to them to try to find out where they had the gold. The leiprechans always tries to get the person to look away. If he did so the person kept his eyes fixed on the leiprechan and persisted in asking to be shown where the gold was he sometimes received some. A leiprechan often threatened to kill anyone that displeased him. The person then tried to save his life by pleasing the leiprechan.

4798689/4790471/4927496.title: The Lepreachan
4798689/4790471/4927496.text: The names the leipreachán is known by locally are leipreachán and geanncanach.  His height is supposed to be only a foot or so.  He is dressed with a green trousers and a red jacket, and a green cap.  He lives under the ground.In former times a man in this district caught him, and endeavoured to get him to give up his gold.  He told him where the gold was, and to go home for a spade but he did not get the gold.Leipreacháns are looked upon as friendly beings.   They have not helped human beings on any occasions.  They have never taken revenge on those who interfered with them.  His only occupation is shoemaking.The mermaid is supposed to be half a fish and half a woman.  People say that she can speak.No one has ever been brought ashore.  Local families are not connected in any way with mermaids.

4798662/4788079/4927537.title: The Leipreachán or Mermaid
4798662/4788079/4927537.text:
The residents of Boyle district, and of the neighbouring districts in general have a great regard for Leipreacháins, fairies and Mermaids, and in consequence a great network of tales and beliefs have sprung up, which, I am sure, if compared with those of other districts in Connaught would greatly surpass them.  These stories, however, are based on actual facts, and, if we may the present-day storytellers, have come down to us, with little or no exaggeration, through scores of yearsThat queer comical little, known locally by the name of Leipreachán, is said to (head to) be no higher than three feet, that is from the top of his head to the soles of his feet.  Persons who saw him, say that he is dressed in a quaint swallow-tail coat just like a gentleman's dress-coat, and a tall tapering hat perched on his head.  None of those who saw him ever (saw him) took notice of his footwear, or if they did they failed to make reference to them in their narrative.  His usual haunt is a fair green hillock, or a dry rocky piece
(continues on next page)

4798690/4790509/4927645.title: A Fairy Tale
4798690/4790509/4927645.text:
Some time ago a band of the neighbouring people used to gather into our house and they used not leave till it would be going on for twelve.  At the crossroads of the Carragarriffe they would not be able to pass.  They would turn back and turn their jackets inside out and turn their caps from back to front but it was of no use until the fairies hour was over.



Pat who was a blacksmith was very fond of money.  He had a fair share of money but still he was not satisfied.One night as Pat sat in a rambling house where a few of the neighbours were gathered he told them of his wish for money and said he "If I got a lot of money I should be very
(continues on next page)

4811582/4799128/4928234.title: The Leipreachán
4811582/4799128/4928234.text:
Many people say the little Leipreachan lives in lonley places. He is like a young child but with an old man's face. He wears a high hat and a red jacket. On his feet there are shoes which are pointed and bells hang from them. His hat is green in colour. On it also hang bells, His pants is yellow. He makes his living by making shoes for the fairies. Old people say he knows where pots of gold are hidden.There is a story of a boy who caught a Leipreachan. He brought him home and locked him in a box. He left him in the box for a few days. One day he came to the box and he told the Leipreachan that he would let him go if he would tell him some good news. The Leipreachan promised him he would. The boy said "do" and the Leipreachan said "your money is stolen". The boy ran to see was his money stolen and when he came back the Leipreachan was gone.Once a man went out at eleven o'clock to a wood where a Leipreachan lived. When he went into the wood he heard a noise not much louder than the ticking of a watch. The man went on and he saw a small man. He kept his eye on him. At last he caught him. He asked him for gold. The little man told him to go home and get a spade.
(continues on next page)

4798685/4790151/4928268.title: Leprechaun or Mermaid
4798685/4790151/4928268.text:
(continued from previous page)
yards from the ground. She took the shawl and said "Get up out of that" to the leipreachan. She walked away and turned back again but the leipreachan was gone.

4798686/4790273/4928371.title: The Leprechaun or Mermaid
4798686/4790273/4928371.text:
The Leipreachan or MermaidThere are not many in this locality who know the Leipreachan but he is generally called the Leipreachan. He is only about six inches in height. He wears a green cap with a big tail hanging out of it and a green tight coat and a big pair of shoes. The Leipreachan generally lives in a fort or under a black thorn bush.The Leapreachan spends his time making shoes. Long long ago there was a very old man who lived in my village. His neighbours were telling him always that he could catch the Leipreachan. One night he went out to catch him and in the middle of the night he caught him. He took the little leipreachan into his hand as quickly as he could and he asked him for the pot of gold. The little leipreachan told him to look towards a certain bush but when he took his eyes from the leipreachan the leipreachan jumped out of his hands and went away.If anyone trys to dig up the bush under which the leipreachan lives
(continues on next page)

4811597/4800436/4928949.title: The Leipreachán or Mermaid
4811597/4800436/4928949.text: The leipreachán is the only name known locally for a 'leipreachán'.  No local person has ever seen him, but it is often they are heard talking of him.  It is believed that he is about the size of a man's fist.  He is supposed to be dressed all in red, red coat and cap, red breeches, red shoes and stockings.  His usual occupation is said to be shoe-making.  Old people say that whenever he is seen, he is always sitting on a mushroom making shoes.It is said he lives in fairy places, in 'lisses' or in furry hill and that he has his crock of gold hidden in these hills.  People believe that anyone who catches him in supposed to keep his or her eyes on him while asking him for gold, for if once your eyes off him, he is gone forever.Written by Mollie CostelloTold by John GalvinKnock

4758551/4754147/4929627.title: A Giant
4758551/4754147/4929627.text:
(continued from previous page)
giant at all.



The Leipreachan is known locally as the Leipreachan. He is about six inches in height. He has a red coat and trousers and cap. He used to live in a small wood called the round O, at Old Court, Inistioge. Shoe making was his occupation. People tried to catch him. They could hear tapping a shoe, but when they came near him he ran away. Sometimes they would be friendly and more times they would not. They are said to be human beings. This is a story told how they helped them. A Leipreachan lived in the Comb, a valley about one hundred yards from Inistioge. At this time there lived in the town a poor shoemaker. He wished he could catch the Leipreachan. This day he said he would look for him. When he came to a certain bush he could hear him tapping a shoe. The shoemaker caught him and asked  him where had he the gold. The Leipreachan told him that someone was calling him
(continues on next page)

4811589/4799704/4930346.title: Leipreachan Story
4811589/4799704/4930346.text:
Leipreachan StoryThere was a field in co. one time. Everyone was supposed to put a cow on it. One morning when they awakened the big field was ploughed and the next morning it was harrowed and they could get grains of wheat in it. After a while the wheat started to grow and grew as big that they used to look up at the head of it. and it all turned into the colom of gold. One evening a whole lot of  men came to see it and they saw a leipreachán in it. One man ran after him and caught him and he asked him who sowed the field of wheat there and he wouldn't tell him.And he asked him where was there a pot of gold then and he wouldn't tell him and they brought him in and put him into an oak
(continues on next page)

4811586/4799364/4931196.title: The Leprechaun
4811586/4799364/4931196.text: Not far from where I live in a little village called Treen a leprechaun was often seen.He was once seen by an old woman milking a cow.

4811590/4799834/4931202.title: The Leipreachan
4811590/4799834/4931202.text: The leipreachan is very small. He is dressed in red and green cloth and has a hammer in his hand. He is met with in very lonely and backward places. He is said always to be shoe - making. Leipreachans are looked upon as being very kindly and any money that is got through the leipreachan is said to be very lucky. The only way he helps human beings is that he reluctantly tells the individual where the gold or money is.When my father was a young boy he knew a man who saw a leipreachan but when he approached near he vanished. After that the people of that village went out every night in hopes of seeing and robbing the leipreachán

4706346/4704667/4931888.title: The Local Forge
4706346/4704667/4931888.text:
(continued from previous page)
The local forges were places for great story tellers and for the latest news. No local Forge has figured in any historical event so far as I know. The only disused forge is that of Mr. Thos Brosnan (of Ballyahinch).N.B.Other accounts of the same subject are similar to the above. Therefore I refrain from giving them in detail.



Shelia Collins says:-"There is not much information to be found about the Leiprechan in this parish. He is known locally as the luibracan. He was seen in the townland of O Brennan up on a ditch by John Sullivan  (R.I.P) He was about 2 feet in height and looked to be young. He wore a little red jacket and a red cap also. He was doing nothing at the time but he had something in his hand like a hammer. As John Sullivan moved towards him he disappeared. The Leipreachan is looked upon as being friendly and harmless." A story is told locally that one of the Geany family of Reamore, Rathanny - 3 miles N.E. of the school saw a leiprechan one moonlight night but when approaching him with uninterrputed gaze to get his gold he lost sight of him. This occurred near the "Bullan" Reamore.

4811592/4800066/4932045.title: The Leipreachán
4811592/4800066/4932045.text:
The LeipreachanThe Leipreachan is known locally as a fairy and a wee little man. He is supposed to be very small, about the size of a blade of grass. He is supposed to wear a red cap and cloak with a breeches to his knees and the shoes with the toes turned up. He is supposed to live in a lonely place, in the shelter of a hedge or a ditch, in a tuft of a grass and under a wild fern. His occupation is supposed to be making and repairing shoes and at the same time watching his crock of gold.It is very difficult to get his gold. Some people when trying to catch him, he tricks them and disappears. Others when they had the gold, put it into a bag with a hole in it and lost it going home and it was turned into buttercups.
(continues on next page)

4811587/4799496/4932908.title: Leipreachan in this District
4811587/4799496/4932908.text:
Leipreachan in this DistrictThere are not many stories about the Leipreachan in this district, only a few I have got from time to time from some of the old people. There is supposed to be a Leipreachan seen in a fort in Mr Gateby's in Gaily, Knockcroghery Bill Kennedy's son lived at the crossroads in Culleen saw the Lipreachan and he tried to take the money off him but he could not.There was also a Leipreachan seen at Anne's Well in Mr Gately's field and he wore a red jacket and a red cap, and shoes curled in at the top made of cow's-hide.Two men named Hubert Coffey and Jack Naughton were coming home from Roscommon and they had a coffin and a dead man in it and a Leipreachan was supposed to have followed the whole way home. The dead man was Jack Egan. A Leipreachan was supposed to have been seen in a sandpit in St John's; it was one of Diffley's children and Grady's children that saw it.Other supernatural beings seen in this district were ban-shees. There was supposed to
(continues on next page)

4769984/4764132/4933058.title: Leprechaun and Mermaid
4769984/4764132/4933058.text:
The Leprecaun is  about nine inches in height. He dresses in a green suit and a red cap.He wears long pointed toed shoes. He lives in raths. He is a shoe maker. No people in the district ever caught him. They are not looked on as friendly people. They have never helped any human being. They have done harm to them. One day my father was ploughing in the field in which he was  there were two blackthorn bushes growing. He ploughed up the bushes and threw them away. He went into his dinner at
(continues on next page)

4769985/4764235/4933162.title: Leprechaun and Mermaid
4769985/4764235/4933162.text:
The lepreacaun is about nine inches in height,He dresses in a green suit and a red cap. He wears long pointed toed shoes.He lives in raths. He is a shoemaker,No people in the district ever caught him, They are not looked on as friendly people. They have never helped any human being. They have done harm to them. One day a man was ploughing. In the field in which he was ploughing there were two blackthorn bushes growing. He ploughed up the bushes growing, He ploughed up the bushes and threw them away.He went into his dinner at twelve o clock, and when he came out the two horses were dead,
(continues on next page)

4922323/4870151/4933307.title: The Leprechaun
4922323/4870151/4933307.text:
The leprechaun was a small fairy that used to be seen it the woods and shady places long ago. He usually wore a red cap with a tassel, a green coat, knee breeches, long stockings, and a pair of small pointed shoes. They were usually seen making or mending shoes, with a small last and hammer.One evening a girl was coming home from a village, and she saw a leprechaun sitting near a bush mending a shoe. She went near him, and asked him to show her where the gold was hidden. He brought her with him to show her the gold. When they were gone a few yards he said to her, "what light is that behind you". She looked back and she saw no light and when she looked again she saw him no more.One November's night, a man was coming home from his "cuard". The night was bright and starry. He heard a ticking noise, and in the shade of a dock-leaf he saw a little fairy dressed in green and a red-hat. He stole up behind him and caught him by the neck. He asked him for some gold. He brought the leprechaun home in a sack, and he put down a pot of water on the fire. He placed the leprechaun on the lid of the pot. Then he told the man he would show him the gold. Then they went off again. He gave the man
(continues on next page)

4769986/4764357/4933399.title: The Leipreachan
4769986/4764357/4933399.text: The leipreachan who lives in lonely places,such as glens and valleys is about two feet high. For clothing he wears a short dark coat and a knee breeches. A man named Maher saw him one night, he tried to catch him and get some of his gold, but he found out that there is no end to his gold, they also say that he was never born. When he would see you he would jump away or hide.He carries the gold in a bag on his back. It is said that no one ever got a hold of his bag.This little man spends his time mending boots. The noise of his hammer is always heard. He works in the moonlight.

4921945/4912237/4934226.title: The Leprechaun and Mermaid
4921945/4912237/4934226.text:
The Leprechaun And Mermaid.The leprechaun is known in this locality as Luhragan.  Nobody whom I know ever saw one, but several remember old people who claim to have seen them.According to the accounts that have come down from those old people, the Luhragan is supposed to be two feet in height and is dressed in a black pants, red coat and a tall peaked cap.  he wears shows with turned up toes.  It is said that he generally lives in a fort and his occupation is shoemaking - He is continually making shoes for the fairies.  He is supposed to work in the open underneath a bush, and keeps a crock of gold hidden somewhere nearby.It is said locally that a man in Loghill caught a Luhragan a long time ago, and held him in his hand until he had to give up the crock of gold.  The man had to keep his eyes fixed on him while he had
(continues on next page)

4921945/4912281/4934340.title: The Leprechaun or Mermaid
4921945/4912281/4934340.text: The Leipreachan is known in my locality as the Lutharagan. It is said that Leipreachan's live in the mountains or forts and that their usual occupation is shoemaking. He is two feet in height and he wears a white cap and a red coat and for shoes he wears sandles with white fur all round. It is said a man caught one in Knockfierna and he took a crock full of gold from him.

4921947/4912404/4934482.title: Paddy Neville and the Leprechaun
4921947/4912404/4934482.text: Paddy Neville and the Leprechaun.A neighbour of mine named Paddy O'Connor told me this story.  He said that a man named Neville worked at McCoy's in Kilcolman.  One morning he went through Jack McDonnell's meadow.  This meadow is near McCoy's.  In the southern corner there is a very shady nook with bushes shading it like a house.  Neville heard the "tic tac", and paused for  a little while.  Then at once he espied the little fellow mending shoes.  he wore a white breeches, green jacket, and a red cap.  Neville stole quietly to the little fellow and caught him and asked him for the gold which he possessed.  The leprechaun answered it was in a big hole under a rock in McCoy's meadow. Neville had to pass over a big fence, but all the time he kept a tight hold of the leprechaun.  As he was trying to get across, he slipped, and off with the leprechaun, helter skelters and not a trace or tidings of the clever little man could he find.  He only heard a laugh in the bushes.  So this is my story of Neville and the leprechaun.

4921962/4913741/4935282.title: The Leprechaun
4921962/4913741/4935282.text:
There was once a boy named Jack. He had no father. He was a lazy fellow and his mother was a poor widow and Jack would not work for her. One day his mother got out her temper with him and she said if you do not work you can go and earn a living for yourself. I am not going to feed a lazy fellow like you. All right, said jack, I'll work for you not for me said Jack she but for a farmer. Jack said he would after his breakfast. When he had his breakfast eaten he set out for the road. He was was walking away until he heard some-yone tapping inside the ditch it was a leprechaun mending a shoe with a little hammer. Jack peeped in over the ditch and he saw the little man dressed in red. Jack made a grab for him and caught him by the arm.
(continues on next page)

4921957/4913243/4935351.title: The Leipreachán or Mermaid
4921957/4913243/4935351.text:
Nellie Fitz.The Leipreacan or Mermaid.The local spirit we hear of, is spriad na Barnagh.  It is said that she travelled several miles in the form of fire.  She killed her husband, and unbaptised child.  It was not long after-wards when she died, and so great were her sins that she would not be allowed into heaven nor hell.  She then appeared in a spirit. At night fall she appeared at the cross of Barnagh, and remained there until the cocks crew in the morning.On one occasion she was met by a man, who was on his way for the priest for his wife.  She stopped him and wanted to kill him, but he asked her to spare him for the sake of his wife.  She said she would if he promised her to come again on the following night, at the same hour, and he promised to do so.  The man went on to the priest's house, and the priest went with him to the sick woman.  After the
(continues on next page)

4921957/4913296/4935437.title: Leipreachán
4921957/4913296/4935437.text: Mary O'Connor,The Commons,Ardagh.Leipreachan.The little leipreachan is known locally as geanncan(?).  He is about five inches in height.  His usual occupation is shoemaking.  Stories are told of people who caught him, but they did not succeed in getting the gold.  Leipreachans are looked upon as friendly beings.One night  a man went out between eleven and twelve o'clock, and not far away from him, he heard a sound like the ticking of a watch.  He came near the place where he heard the sound, and saw there a leipreachan.  He caught hold of him, and said he would not let him go, until he would get the gold.  Then, "Look at that behind you", said the leipreachan, "Mind for fear he would bite you".  The man looked and as soon as he did the leipreachan was gone.Told to me by my mother.Mrs. O'Connor,The Commons,Ardagh.

4921957/4913307/4935461.title: The Leipreachán or Mermaid
4921957/4913307/4935461.text:
Bridie Ambrose,Eneghare,Ardagh,Co. Limerick.The Leipreacan or Mermaid.There is no tradition of a leipreacan having his abode in my district, but the leipreachan is known as a little man who lives in some parts of Ireland.  He wears a bright red jacket, and has a long white beard. His sole occupation is shoemaking and he is supposed to be the posessor of a large crock of gold.  It is a tradition that if a person caught him, and demanded the crock of gold from him, that he would in due time surrender, but people who were fortunate in catching him, were unknown to themselves, made let loose their treasure by the swiftness of the little man.The mermaid is a sea creature with the head of a woman and the tail of  a fish.  She is seen combing her hair on the rocks in Ballybunion, before a drowning takes place.Spriad na Barnagh, was an old hag, who
(continues on next page)

4758590/4757275/4936318.title: The Leipreachán
4758590/4757275/4936318.text:
In my district the leipreacán is called a fairy or geanncanach. His height is about two feet and he is dressed in a red coat and he wears a red cap with a point on the top of it and he wears a pair of shoes with toes in them. The leipreacán lives in a fort or in a very lonely field and it is said that he sits on a mushroom. His usual occupation is making shoes and mending shoes. The leipreacán is looked upon as a friendly being. The old people say that it is not right to  interfere with the fairies. It is said that if you caught a fairy and took his cap from him he would give you the crock of gold if you give him the cap back. If you saw a fairy and kept

4922020/4919243/4937109.title: Lepreachaun
4922020/4919243/4937109.text: LeipreachánAbout twenty years ago one evening at five o clock Mrs McKnight, deceased, of Beigh was going for a bucket of water to a well some fields from her home.  As she was going along the field she heard a roar and looking back saw a small little man running after her who was about to hit her with a stick.  She called her husband who was working in some fields nearby.  He heard her call and went to help her. As he was near the woman, the little fairy went in among the bushes and disappeared and he was never again seen.  He wore a blue tall cap with two little tossels hanging off it, a red coat with brass buttons, and a pair of blue shoes with silver buckles.  When the woman came home she went to bed and had to remain there for a week as a result of the fright.Ciss Mc KnightBeighFrom Richard McKnight Aged 47Beigh.

4922020/4919244/4937112.title: Lepreachán
4922020/4919244/4937112.text: Mrs Nolan of Ballinorth, formerly Miss Kelly, was gathering fire-wood one evening when she was twenty years old.  She saw in the furze near her home, a little man dressed in a red suit, with a blue cap and tassel.  She immediately turned around to call her sister and on looking back discovered he had vanished.  Then her father rooted up the furze but found nothing.  It happened one day that the furze were brought in and burned.  Next morning when the ashes were taken out, the family found thirty large pieces of silver, which they carried to Limerick and exchanged for a large sum of money.Ellen SheehyIssaneFrom Mrs Kate Sheehy 50 yearsIssane

4921959/4913522/4938293.title: The Leprechauns
4921959/4913522/4938293.text: Long ago a man lived in Glensharrold who dreamt on the succeeding nights that gold was concealed in a certain field not very far away from his house. To be successful in getting the gold he should dig for it about midnight. So he started off one night with a spade and pickaxe borrowed from a neighbour to dig for the gold. As he was crossing a bridge which led to the field, he stopped for a minute to rest. He heard bittling[?] under the bridge (that was the way clothes were washed long ago). He proceeded on his way and soon reached the field where the treasure was supposed to be. To his surprise he saw coming out the gap hundreds of little men about one foot high, each carrying a bundle on his back and a bittle[?] in his hand facing for the bridge to do their bittling[?] The poor man concealed himself behind a brush. There was an old Witch in the centre of the field giving orders and she said "Go over to that bush and see what is there." So hundreds of them surrounded him and every one attacked him with his bittle[?]. He defended himself as best he could but there were too many against him. So he made for his home as quickly as he could go. When he went for his implements in the morning he discovered that the handles of the pick-axe and spade were chewed off.

4922007/4917813/4941230.title: Leprechauns
4922007/4917813/4941230.text: Mr. Patrick Roche of Ballingarry was cutting hay one day in Lois na  bfiann fort when a lepreachán appeared to him. He caught the lepreachán. The leipreacán gave him a special charm to let him go. This charm was that he need'nt ever edge his scythe. This was a great boon in those days because there were no machines. Mr. Roche never had to edge his scythe afterwards. He never got tired no matter how long he mowed. This is suffered to happen about 100 yrs. ago.

4723869/4720926/4941320.title: Leipreachán or Mermaid
4723869/4720926/4941320.text: No one in this district ever saw a Leipreachan and those who heard of one say that he was a small man dressed in red clothes and was a shoe-maker. He was supposed to have lots of gold which he got for the work  he did for the fairies. The Leipreachan was regarded as a friendly being & supposed to be very helpful to those who liked him.The old people never heard of a mermaid appearing in this district.

4742053/4731232/4941727.title: A Leipreachán
4742053/4731232/4941727.text: One day a little girl named Monaghan was sitting at a lone bush herding cattle & she fell asleep. She was wakened by someone throwing stones at her. She got up & looked around, & saw a wee little man dressed in a green coat & red trousers & cap. She knew it was a leipreachan & she asked him where the crock of gold was. Then he said "look over at the cows." & when she turned back he was gone. She knew she had lost her chance.

The race of people that came to Ireland after Clanna Neimhid were named as Fir Bolgs or Bag Men. When the De Danans came they beat the Bag Men in a battle. The Bag Men ran into the caves and holes in the ground and were not seen by day only by night. They were called Fairies and Leprachauns and were only twelve inches in height.It is said that the Leprachauans were the richest people in the world.One moonlight night when Captian Sheahan visited the Deel Forth he saw three Leprachauns carrying three pots of gold to their den. 4921979/4915031/4942760.title: The Leprechaun or Mermaid
4921979/4915031/4942760.text: The Leprechaun or Mermaid The Leprechaun is supposed to be a fairy shoemaker usually lives in forts or quiet places away from civilisation. They were much sought after by people for their gold as they are supposed to have plenty of gold for disposal if captured by any human being. They are very small and friendly men about six inches high ususlly dressed in a red coat. They are always supposed to be very industrious making fairy shoes. Leprechauns have very often helped people by giving money when they were in want.The Mermaid lives at the bottom of the sea. She has a womans face and body and a fish's tail. The Mermaid often appears on the shore and it is said if any person saw it that person would get drowned.

4921993/4916276/4947190.title: The Leprechauns
4921993/4916276/4947190.text: [Title is spelt as "the Leipreachans"]Last summer, it was rumoured that leipreachans visited Ballingarry a village situated two miles from Kilmeedy. It appears that they were dressed in red coats, white capes and knee breeches and wearing vamps instead of shoes. It is said that they were less than two feet high, with hard, hairy faces, short fingers, and no ears. These leipreachans caused great excitement in the surrounding districts and crowds used to assemble every evening betweem Ballingarry and Kilfinny hoping to catch a glimpse of them but we later learned that the whole story was invented by children.Traditions says that leipreachans live in forts and caves and their usual occupation is shoemaking. No one ever succeeded in catching one of these people as they are supposed to be able to run as fast as greyhounds.
